For example, during early embryonic development, the optic vesicle of the brain releases certain signaling molecules that travel to nearby cells. These molecules activate the expression of certain genes in those nearby cells, which eventually leads to the development of the optic lens. The optic vesicle just “induced” the development of lens cells. Remember, induction does not mean that the optic vesicle is turned into the lens of the eye. Rather, induction is the instruction of nearby cells to develop into a certain tissue or structure. Therefore, Option D , Induction , is the correct answer. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Transformation – This option is incorrect because transformation does not involve one cell directing the development of another cell. Instead, transformation is when a bacterial cell absorbs exogenous DNA from its surroundings and incorporates it internally. Transformation is very useful to bacteria because it can increase genetic diversity or introduce new traits such as antibiotic resistance. While transformation is a powerful way for bacterial cells to influence each other, it does not direct the development of a cell or group of cells, which makes this answer option incorrect. Option B. Transduction – This option is incorrect because transduction does not direct the development of a group of cells. Rather, transduction occurs when a bacteriophage virus transfers genetic material from one bacterium to another. The new cell now serves as a host cell and will be used to further spread the virus to more bacterial cells. Because this involves the sharing of genetic material between individuals who are not parent-offspring, it is referred to as horizontal gene transfer. While transduction can induce big changes in a cell’s function due to a virus, it does not induce a change in the development of another cell, which makes this answer option incorrect. Option C. Transcription– This option is incorrect because transcription is not a process that induces development in cells. Instead, transcription is the process by which DNA is used as a template to create a single strand of mRNA (messenger RNA). In eukaryotes, once the mRNA molecule is created, it is shuttled out of the nucleus and into the cytosol where translation can occur. Transcription does not direct the development of another cell; therefore, this answer option is incorrect. Option E. Conjugation – This option is incorrect because conjugation does not direct the development of another cell. During conjugation, bacteria transfer DNA between each other via a cytoplasmic bridge, known as a pili. This shared DNA is often in the form of a plasmid and can serve to spread beneficial traits such as antibiotic resistance. Because this involves the sharing of genetic material between individuals who are not parent-offspring, it is referred to as horizontal gene transfer.

question.text: A mutation causes all of the mitochondria of a cell to be dysfunctional. Which of the following processes would likely not be affected by this mutation?

explanation.concept_text: The mitochondrion is a membrane-bound organelle found in almost all eukaryotic cells. Parts of the mitochondrion include the outer membrane, the inner membrane which has many cristae (folds), the intermembrane space, and the mitochondrial matrix (space enclosed by the inner membrane). Its main function is to generate ATP by being the site of several metabolic processes. If a mutation occurs and the mitochondria become dysfunctional, all of the processes occurring within the mitochondria will be affected. These processes include pyruvate oxidation (occurs in the matrix), the citric acid cycle (occurs in the matrix), the electron transport chain (embedded in the inner membrane), and oxidative phosphorylation (occurs in the intermembrane space and inner membrane). The only process of cellular respiration that does not occur within the mitochondria is glycolysis and hence, will not be affected if the mitochondria become dysfunctional. As seen in the figure below, glycolysis is the catalysis of glucose into two molecules of pyruvate, which yields a net gain of 2 molecules of ATP via substrate-level phosphorylation and occurs in the cytosol of the eukaryotic cell – independent of the mitochondria. Therefore, the correct answer to this question is Option B , Glycolysis .
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Pyruvate oxidation – This option is incorrect because pyruvate oxidation occurs inside the mitochondrion, therefore, a dysfunctional mitochondrion would be unable to carry out this process. After pyruvate is produced by glycolysis, it enters the mitochondrion and is converted to acetyl CoA via pyruvate oxidation. Acetyl CoA then enters the Citric Acid Cycle and continues facilitating the production of ATP. In general terms, pyruvate oxidation links glycolysis to the citric acid cycle, and occurs inside the mitochondrial matrix, which makes this answer option incorrect. Option C. Citric acid cycle – This option is incorrect because the citric acid cycle (a.k.a. Krebs Cycle) occurs in the mitochondrial matrix. A dysfunctional mitochondrion would be unable to carry out this process. After pyruvate enters the mitochondrion, it is converted into acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA then enters the Citric Acid Cycle to be broken down and form CO 2 , ATP, NADH, and FADH 2 . The electron carriers NADH and FADH 2 will then shuttle electrons to the electron transport chain to power ATP production. Because the Citric Acid Cycle cannot occur without fully functioning mitochondria, this answer option is incorrect. Option D. Electron transport chain – This option is incorrect because the electron transport chain (ETC) is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane, therefore, it cannot occur if mitochondria are dysfunctional. As seen in the figure above, the ETC is responsible for the majority of ATP production in aerobic respiration (approximately 32 ATP molecules). The ETC begins with NADH and FADH 2 donating electrons to cytochromes (protein carriers) embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. The electrons are then passed down a series of protein complexes to create a proton gradient across the mitochondrial inner membrane. The potential energy harvested from these electrons moving to progressively lower free energy levels is later coupled with ATP synthase enzymes to produce ATP. Since the electron transport chain is located in the inner mitochondrial membrane, this process cannot occur without fully functioning mitochondria, which makes this answer option incorrect. Option E. Oxidative phosphorylation – This option is incorrect because oxidative phosphorylation takes place inside mitochondria. Oxidative phosphorylation is the synthesis of ATP using the energy harvested from the redox reactions in the electron transport chain. This is unlike substrate-level phosphorylation (used by glycolysis), which directly generates ATP by having an enzyme transfer a substrate’s phosphate group to an ADP molecule. Since oxidative phosphorylation depends on the electron transport chain and occurs in the inner mitochondrial membrane, it cannot occur in dysfunctional mitochondria, which makes this answer option incorrect.

question.text: Which of the following phylum has radial symmetry?

explanation.concept_text: Before we tackle the specifics of this question, it is useful to take a zoomed-out view first. Recall that all eukaryotes fall into one of four kingdoms: Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia . The kingdom Animalia (animals) is further categorized in the phyla listed below: Organisms from the phyla Cnidaria and Echinodermata are the only two phyla that display radial symmetry; that is, their body parts are arranged around a central axis. In contrast, all other phyla have bilateral symmetry – except for the phylum Porifera, which is asymmetrical . Therefore, Option A , Echinodermata , is the correct answer. Examples of Phylum Echinodermata include starfish and sea urchins. The general shape and body parts of these animals are symmetrically divided in half along many different lines that pass through their central point, like dividing a pizza in half. The illustration below depicts this concept. For the test, you should memorize all the animal phyla in the list above, along with their respective characteristics. This question tests your knowledge of body plan symmetry (i.e. asymmetrical vs radial vs bilateral); however, you are just as likely to be asked about tissue organization (i.e. diploblast vs triploblast), coelom formation (i.e. acoelomate vs pseudocoelomate vs true coelomate), or embryonic development (i.e. protostome vs deuterostome). To see a detailed comparison between all the animal phyla and their corresponding characteristics, please refer to the Animalia Phyla Study Sheet . CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Arthropoda – This option is incorrect because Arthropoda do not exhibit radial symmetry; rather, Arthropoda exhibit bilateral symmetry. Furthermore, Arthropoda have coelomate bodies, a chitin exoskeleton, and multiple pairs of jointed appendages. Having more species than all other animal phyla combined, Arthropoda is the largest animal phylum (around 85 percent of all animals are arthropods) and includes spiders, insects, and crustaceans. Option C. Mollusca – This option is incorrect because they do not exhibit radial symmetry; rather, Mollusca exhibit bilateral symmetry. Mollusks have coelomate bodies, complete digestive tracts, and usually have open circulatory systems with an internal cavity called the hemocoel. A few examples of mollusks are snails, octopuses, squids, and bivalves. Option D. Porifera – This option is incorrect because Porifera exhibit an asymmetrical body plan. Porifera are more commonly known as sponges, and they are the oldest animal phylum. They feed by filtering water through their sponge walls, and they are capable of reproducing both sexually and asexually. Porifera are commonly used in the production of antibiotic medication because they host a diverse range of bacteria. Option E. Rotifera – This option is incorrect because they do not exhibit radial symmetry; instead, Rotifera exhibit bilateral symmetry. Rotifera are filter feeders, have a pseudocoelom, and are capable of parthenogenesis – a type of asexual reproduction.

question.text: What type of organism was responsible for the creation of the ozone layer?

explanation.concept_text: Ozone is a molecule with the formula O 3 (three oxygen atoms linked together). The ozone layer is a section of the earth’s atmosphere where ozone molecules are found in relatively high concentration, and it is crucial to life as we know it because it absorbs most of the sun’s harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation . Depletion of the ozone layer would lead to catastrophic consequences for most organisms on Earth. The only organisms that would remain largely unaffected are extremophiles, due to their high tolerance to extreme conditions like high UV radiation, high salinity, or extremely high & low temperatures. In fact, this is what the first form of life on earth looked like billions of years ago. Let us go over a timeline of Earth’s development to help us tackle this question: In summary, around 2.5 billion years ago some prokaryotes developed the ability to perform photosynthesis, which classified them as autotrophs. Through photosynthesis, these autotrophic prokaryotes released oxygen into Earth’s atmosphere, which eventually led to the Great Oxidation Event and, subsequently, the creation of the ozone layer. Therefore, Option A , Autotrophic prokaryotes , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Anaerobic eukaryotes – This option is incorrect because the ozone layer was formed by a certain type of prokaryotes – note eukaryotes. Specifically, it was formed by cyanobacteria. In addition, eukaryotes are believed to have appeared after the oxygenation of the Earth’s atmosphere. Once formed, the ozone layer absorbed a significant portion of UV radiation entering the atmosphere, which converted the previously hostile conditions into much more hospitable habitats, thus allowing new life to appear, likely including eukaryotes. Option C. Sponges – This option is incorrect because sponges appeared long after the creation of the ozone layer (at least two billion years later). Sponges are eukaryotes and are members of the kingdom Animalia and the phylum Porifera, which could not have formed before the protection provided by the ozone layer, which makes this answer option incorrect. Option D. Heterotrophic eukaryotes – This option is incorrect because heterotrophs , by definition, are incapable of producing their own food; they obtain energy by consuming organic matter. Since oxygen is produced by autotrophs performing photosynthesis, heterotrophs could not have been responsible for the creation of the ozone layer. Moreover, all eukaryotes (including heterotrophic eukaryotes) are believed to have appeared after the creation of the ozone layer due to the protection it provided from UV radiation. Option E. Fungi – This option is incorrect because fungi are heterotrophs and they do not produce oxygen as a byproduct of their metabolism. Recall that heterotrophs are incapable of producing their own food. Since oxygen is produced by autotrophs performing photosynthesis, heterotrophs could not have been responsible for the creation of the ozone layer. Moreover, fungi appeared after the creation of the ozone layer.

question.text: Alpha helices and beta-pleated sheets are formed and reinforced by which form of bonding?

explanation.concept_text: Proteins are polypeptides that can have up to four levels of structure: Primary, Secondary, Tertiary, and Quaternary. The primary structure is composed of a linear series of amino acids linked together via peptide bonds (hence the term poly peptide ). The secondary structure is composed of polypeptides that are bent into alpha helices and beta-pleated sheets . As shown in the image below, this morphing of the polypeptide into a 3D shape is made possible by hydrogen bonding between the carbonyl oxygen and amino hydrogen of nearby amino acids. The tertiary structure is the 3D structure formed primarily due to interactions between amino acid R groups such as hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic interactions, Van der Waals forces, ionic bonding, and disulfide bonds. Lastly, the quaternary structure is a group of two or more separate peptide chains being held together by interactions similar to those in tertiary structures. Because alpha helices and beta-pleated sheets are a direct result of hydrogen bonding, the correct answer is Option D , Hydrogen bonding . Note: Denaturation refers to the disruption or complete destruction of the interactions between secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures only – denaturation does not affect the peptide bonds of the primary structure, but it does render the protein non-functional. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Ionic bonding – This option is incorrect because ionic bonds do not contribute to primary structures of proteins – instead, they play an important role in tertiary and quaternary structures. Ionic bonds are a result of oppositely charged side chains coming into close contact. For example, an ionic bond can form between a positively charged lysine and a negatively charged aspartic acid. These interactions help to stabilize the folded shape of the protein (tertiary structure) and can be important in the assembly of multi-subunit proteins (quaternary structure). Option B. Disulfide bonds – This option is incorrect because disulfide bonds do not contribute to primary structures. Rather, disulfide bonds are observed in tertiary and quaternary structures as they are interactions between side chains of amino acids (R groups). Specifically, cysteine is the only amino acid that forms disulfide bonds. Although tertiary structures are held together by non-covalent interactions, disulfide bonds are an exception and are considered covalent bonds. As such, they offer a relatively strong linkage between cysteine groups and firmly hold the 3D shape of the tertiary structure. Option C. Hydrophobic effect – This option is incorrect because this is mostly observed in tertiary and quaternary structures since the hydrophobic effect is considered to be an interaction between side chains of amino acids. Due to the aqueous nature of the cytoplasm surrounding proteins, tertiary structures fold in a way that clusters the hydrophobic side chains together in the core of the structure, minimizing exposure to water. Option E. – This option is incorrect because it is actually non-covalent interactions that form alpha helices and beta-pleated sheets. Recall that a covalent bond involves the equal sharing of an electron pair between two atoms (e.g. in an H 2 molecule, two hydrogen atoms form a covalent bond by sharing a pair of electrons). In contrast, alpha helices and beta-pleated sheets are formed through hydrogen bonding , which is a type of non-covalent interaction. Hydrogen bonding occurs between the partially positively charged hydrogen of one molecule and the partially negatively charged electronegative atom (N, O, or F) of a different molecule.

question.text: Which of the following processes yields the most ATP?

explanation.concept_text: ATP (Adenosine triphosphate) is the primary energy currency of living cells, and it powers countless biochemical pathways in nature. Three common methods for ATP production are cellular respiration, substrate-level phosphorylation, and photosynthesis. The highest ATP yield is achieved by cellular respiration , which is made up of distinct biochemical pathways and processes. Cellular respiration breaks down glucose molecules to generate ATP. The breakdown of glucose begins with glycolysis, which occurs in the cell cytoplasm. Glycolysis uses substrate-level phosphorylation to produce a net gain of 2 ATP molecules, two pyruvate molecules, and two NADH. Each pyruvate molecule enters the mitochondrion and undergoes pyruvate oxidation to be converted into acetyl-CoA (acetyl coenzyme A). Each acetyl-CoA then enters the Citric Acid Cycle (a.k.a. Krebs cycle ) which involves a series of biochemical steps to produce one ATP, three NADH, and one FADH 2 (high-energy electron carriers). However, keep in mind that two pyruvates are produced per one glucose molecule, therefore, the ATP output of the Krebs cycle per glucose molecule is 2 ATP . The high-energy electron carriers are then used to power the Electron Transport Chain (ETC) which is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. The ETC creates a proton gradient that drives ATP production via oxidative phosphorylation, yielding 32 ATP molecules (majority of ATP in cellular respiration). In summary, glycolysis yields 2 ATP, the Krebs cycle yields 2 ATP, and the Electron Transport Chain yields 32 ATP per molecule of glucose. Therefore, Option D , Electron Transport Chain , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Glycolysis – This option is incorrect because glycolysis produces much fewer ATP molecules when compared to the Electron Transport Chain (two ATP vs 32 ATP, respectively). Glycolysis can be viewed as having an “energy investment” and an “energy payoff” phase. The investment pathway requires 2 ATP molecules to be carried out, however, the subsequent payoff pathway generates a total of four ATP molecules, bringing the net gain from glycolysis to 2 ATP molecules. Option B. Krebs cycle – This option is incorrect because the Krebs cycle produces much fewer ATP molecules when compared to the Electron Transport Chain (two ATP vs 32 ATP, respectively). Although the Krebs cycle produces some ATP, this is not the primary role of this pathway. Rather the Krebs cycle primarily serves to generate high-energy electron carriers (NADH and FADH 2 ) to carry high-energy electrons to the electron transport chain. Option C. Fermentation – This option is incorrect because fermentation does not produce any ATP. Rather, the purpose of fermentation is the oxidation of NADH to regenerate NAD+. As glycolysis occurs, the cell’s supply of NAD+ is eventually converted to NADH. For glycolysis to be able to continue when no oxygen is available, the NAD+ must be regenerated through a method other than aerobic cellular respiration. Fermentation converts NADH back into NAD+, allowing glycolysis to continue even in anaerobic conditions. Option E. Cori cycle – This option is incorrect because the Cori cycle does not directly produce ATP. Instead, the primary function of the Cori cycle is to recycle lactate produced by muscles during anaerobic conditions. The Cori cycle occurs in the liver, and it converts lactate back into glucose, which can be sent to energy-hungry muscles and tissues. Not only does the Cori cycle not produce any ATP, but it consumes ATP to carry out its functions.

question.text: In humans when a female is born, the development of her oocyte is arrested in which of the following stages?

explanation.concept_text: In females, meiosis begins during the fetal stage. Oogenesis occurs in steps, before birth, after puberty, and during fertilization. The cells starting meiosis are called primary oocytes. These cells will begin the first meiotic division, but their progress is arrested in prophase I of meiosis. Therefore, Option B , Prophase I of meiosis , is the correct answer. The primary oocytes gather in the ovary and at the time of birth, all future eggs are in the prophase stage. Upon reaching puberty, hormonal signals trigger one primary oocyte per cycle to resume meiosis and develop into a secondary oocyte. The secondary oocyte begins meiosis II but is arrested again at metaphase II. If fertilization occurs, meiosis II goes on to completion. Below is an illustration to help visualize this concept. Note the number of chromosomes sets along each stage (1n vs 2n). Females are born with oocytes that are 2n because meiosis I has not gone to completion yet. It is only after the completion of meiosis that the diploid primary oocyte becomes a haploid secondary oocyte. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Prophase II of meiosis – This option is incorrect because oogenesis is arrested at prophase I at birth, resulting in a diploid primary oocyte. It is only after puberty that meiosis continues to form a haploid secondary oocyte and a polar body. A meiotic arrest occurs, this time at the metaphase II stage. If the secondary oocyte is fertilized, the cell continues through meiosis II, completing meiosis, producing a second polar body and a haploid ovum, which fuses with the sperm nucleus to form the diploid zygote. Option C. Prophase of mitosis – This option is incorrect because gametogenesis is the production of sperm (spermatogenesis) and eggs (oogenesis) through the process of meiosis, not mitosis. Recall that mitosis gives rise to diploid cells that are genetically identical, whereas meiosis gives rise to haploid cells (gametes) that are genetically unique. The purpose of reproduction is to give rise to a genetically unique and diverse offspring; therefore, proper function of meiosis is crucial. Option D. Metaphase I of meiosis – This option is incorrect because oogenesis is arrested at prophase I at birth, resulting in a diploid primary oocyte. After puberty, meiosis continues, to form a haploid secondary oocyte and a polar body. A meiotic arrest occurs, this time at the metaphase II stage. If the secondary oocyte is fertilized, the cell continues through meiosis II, completing meiosis, producing a second polar body and a haploid ovum, which fuses with the sperm nucleus to form the diploid zygote. Option E. Metaphase II of meiosis – This option is incorrect because oogenesis is arrested at prophase I at birth, resulting in a diploid primary oocyte. The eggs are arrested at metaphase II of meiosis only after puberty. Once puberty has begun, meiosis continues, to form a haploid secondary oocyte and a polar body. A meiotic arrest occurs, this time at the metaphase II stage. If the secondary oocyte is fertilized, the cell continues through meiosis II, completing meiosis, producing a second polar body and a haploid ovum, which fuses with the sperm nucleus to form the diploid zygote.

question.text: A plant-like unicellular organism with a nucleus is best categorized under which kingdom?

explanation.concept_text: All life on earth falls under one of three domains : Archaea, Bacteria, and Eukarya. These three domains are further subdivided into six kingdoms : Eubacteria (bacteria), Archaebacteria (Archaea), Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia. This question is testing your knowledge of the six kingdoms of life and their characteristics. For the test, it is important to know the general characteristics of each of the six kingdoms, outlined in the table below. The question mentions that the organism of interest is plant-like , unicellular , and with a nucleus . To answer this question let us look at the three properties individually and find the answer option that matches the description best. CC BY 4.0 In summary, Protista is a group of eukaryotic and unicellular organisms. They have a nucleus that is surrounded by a nuclear envelope. Additionally, some protists are plant-like and can perform photosynthesis. Therefore, the correct answer is Option D. Protista .
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Animalia – This option is incorrect because all organisms of the class Animalia are, by definition, multicellular and heterotrophic. In contrast, the organism mentioned in the question is unicellular and plant-like (i.e. heterotrophic). Option B. Plantae – This option is incorrect because all plants are, by definition, multicellular organisms. In contrast, the organism mentioned in the question is unicellular. While there are some unicellular organisms that can perform photosynthesis (e.g. algae), these organisms belong to the kingdom Protista – not Plantae. Option C. Monera – This option is incorrect because Monera are unicellular organisms that do not have nuclei. You may have noticed that Monera is not one of the six kingdoms listed in the table above. An older method of classification used to group kingdom Bacteria and kingdom Archaea together as the kingdom Monera (essentially all prokaryotes) because of some similarities such as the lack of membrane-bound organelles. However, further taxonomic research revealed that Bacteria and Archaea are fairly different; therefore, the kingdom Monera was dropped and split into the kingdoms of Eubacteria (bacteria) and Archaebacteria (Archaea). Option E. Fungi – This option is incorrect because fungi are not plant-like. Fungi can exist as either unicellular or multicellular organisms. However, one of the defining characteristics of fungi is that they are heterotrophs. That is, they cannot produce their own food (through processes such as photosynthesis) and, instead, must consume other organisms to obtain nutrients.

question.text: An extremely premature baby who is not producing surfactant will experience the following consequence __________.

explanation.concept_text: As the functional unit of the lungs, alveoli are the tiny air sacs where gas exchange occurs with overlying capillaries. Because alveoli are spherical in shape and lined with water, the surface tension on the water-air interface produces a large force acting inward that can “collapse” the sacks, which would render them unusable, as seen in the figure below. To prevent this, healthy individuals have a layer of surfactant that coats the inner surface of the alveoli.  Surfactant is a phospholipid-rich substance produced by Type II alveolar cells and functions to reduce the surface tension in the alveoli. There is much less surface tension in the surfactant-air interface when compared to the water-air interface. Hence, the tendency for alveoli to collapse inward is significantly reduced with a lining of surfactant. Therefore, Option C. Collapsed alveoli , is the correct answer to this question. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Decreased metabolism – This option is incorrect because an individual's metabolism (or rate of metabolism) is not directly affected by the presence or absence of surfactant. Instead, one of the most common direct causes of decreased metabolism is hypothyroidism, which involves the under-secretion of T3 and T4 hormones. In healthy individuals, the secretion levels of T3 and T4 are in a healthy balance with the rest of the biochemical needs of the body, and these hormones function to increase the metabolic rate. In the case of under-secretion of these hormones, the consequences will likely include a decreased metabolism, weight gain, fatigue, and sensitivity to cold. Option B. Lack of stomach mucus – This option is incorrect because an individual's ability to produce stomach mucus is not directly affected by the presence or absence of surfactant. Instead, lack of stomach mucus would be the result of dysfunctional mucous cells. These cells are located in the lining of the stomach, and they excrete a consistent supply of mucus that lubricates and protects the stomach lining from the acidic environment. However, the presence of surfactant is not directly affected or regulated by stomach mucus, as it is an entirely separate substance found in a different area of the body. Option D. Lower bone calcium – This option is incorrect because an individual's bone calcium levels are not directly affected by the presence or absence of surfactant. Recall that bone calcium and blood calcium levels are both regulated by the hormones calcitonin and parathyroid hormone (PTH). Calcitonin lowers blood calcium levels and raises bone calcium by inhibiting the activity of osteoclasts (cells that break down bone to release calcium). In contrast, PTH raises blood calcium and lowers bone calcium by stimulating osteoclast activity. Therefore, lower bone calcium would not be caused by a lack of surfactant, rather it would be directly caused by low calcitonin levels or high PTH levels. Option E. Reduced night vision – This option is incorrect because an individual's night vision is not directly affected by the presence or absence of surfactant. Instead, night vision (i.e. the ability to see in low-light environments) is driven by rod cells in the eye. The two types of photoreceptors found in the retina of the eyes are rod cells and cone cells. Rods function in environments with little light and cones function in environments with lots of light to transmit color and sharp images. Use the mnemonic “C for Color” to remember the difference. Therefore, reduced night vision would not be caused by a lack of surfactant, rather it would be directly caused by a lack of or dysfunction of the rod cells in the eye’s retina.

question.text: Which of the following correctly describes an acrosomal reaction?

options.label: A.
options.text: A reaction that prevents the entry of more sperm into the egg with a wave of Calcium ions that causes the egg's protein envelope to harden and sperm receptors to degrade

options.label: B.
options.text: A reaction that occurs after the blastula stage of development

options.label: C.
options.text: A reaction that occurs when the two haploid nuclei of the sperm and egg fuse into a diploid nucleus

options.label: D.
options.text: A reaction that degrades the protective coat and protein membrane surrounding the egg

options.label: E.
options.text: A reaction that happens directly after the cortical reaction

correct_answer_text: A reaction that degrades the protective coat and protein membrane surrounding the egg

explanation.concept_text: The acrosome is an organelle over the anterior half of the sperm’s head. It contains digestive enzymes including hyaluronidase and acrosin. The acrosome reaction is a crucial step during gamete interaction in all species, including humans. It allows spermatozoa to penetrate the zone pellucida of the egg and fuse with the oocyte membrane. The zona pellucida is a thick, transparent, glycoprotein membrane that surrounds the cell’s plasma membrane. Spermatozoa unable to undergo the acrosome reaction will not fertilize intact oocytes. Here is an illustration to help you understand this concept: CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. A reaction that prevents the entry of more sperm into the egg with a wave of calcium ions that causes the egg’s protein envelope to harden and sperm receptors to degrade – This option is incorrect because the acrosomal reaction actually refers to the process that degrades the protective coat and protein membrane surrounding the egg. Option B. A reaction that occurs after the blastula stage of development – This option is incorrect because the acrosomal reaction actually refers to the process that degrades the protective coat and protein membrane surrounding the egg. Option C. A reaction that occurs when the two haploid nuclei of the sperm and egg fuse into a diploid nucleus – This option is incorrect because the acrosomal reaction actually refers to the process that degrades the protective coat and protein membrane surrounding the egg. Option E. A reaction that happens directly after the cortical reaction – This option is incorrect because the acrosomal reaction actually refers to the process that degrades the protective coat and protein membrane surrounding the egg.

question.text: Which of the following is true of autosomal recessive conditions?

options.label: A.
options.text: Males will have the condition more often

options.label: B.
options.text: Females will have the condition more often

options.label: C.
options.text: Homozygous dominant individuals will be affected by the condition

options.label: D.
options.text: Two unaffected parents cannot have an affected child

options.label: E.
options.text: Heterozygotes will not be affected by the condition

correct_answer_text: Heterozygotes will not be affected by the condition

explanation.concept_text: First, let us recall the difference between genes vs alleles. A gene is a stretch of DNA that codes for a trait or characteristic, whereas an allele codes for the specific variant of that trait. For example, two siblings both have the gene for eye color, however, one has the “green” allele while the other has the “brown” allele. Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes, each carrying one allele from the father and one allele from the mother. The first 22 pairs are called autosomal chromosomes , and they influence almost the entire body except for sexual development. The 23 rd pair are the sex chromosomes (X and Y), which determine biological sex and drive sexual development. Since the question presents an autosomal scenario, we know that it does not involve the sex chromosomes, therefore, biological sex will be irrelevant in the inheritance of this specific condition. Therefore, Options A and B are incorrect. Dominant vs recessive refers to how alleles interact with each other to determine the phenotype being expressed by the organism. A dominant allele will express its corresponding trait even if there is only one copy of the allele present. In contrast, a recessive allele is expressed only if two copies of the allele are present. Dominant alleles “mask” or “overrule” the expression of a recessive allele when paired together. A homozygous individual carries two identical alleles (e.g. AA or aa). A heterozygous individual carries two different alleles (e.g. Aa). If a condition is autosomal recessive , as mentioned in the question, then both alleles must be recessive for the condition to be expressed (e.g. aa). A heterozygote individual cannot be affected by an autosomal recessive condition because both alleles need to be in the recessive form, but heterozygotes carry two different alleles. Therefore, Option E , Heterozygotes will not be affected by the condition , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Males will have the condition more often – This option is incorrect because biological sex is irrelevant in the inheritance of autosomal conditions. Recall that only sex-linked conditions are affected by sex. If a condition is said to be “autosomal” like the example in this question, then, by definition, the condition is not sex-linked because autosomal refers to the first 22 chromosomes (which are not the sex chromosomes X & Y). As such, a person’s sex does not influence the chances of being affected by an autosomal recessive condition. Option B. Females will have the condition more often – This option is incorrect because biological sex is irrelevant in the inheritance of autosomal conditions. Recall that only sex-linked conditions are affected by sex. If a condition is said to be “autosomal” like the example in this question, then, by definition, the condition is not sex-linked because autosomal refers to the first 22 chromosomes (which are not the sex chromosomes X & Y). As such, a person’s sex does not influence the chances of being affected by an autosomal recessive condition. Option C. Homozygous dominant individuals will be affected by the condition – This option is incorrect because a homozygous dominant individual will not carry any of the alleles responsible for the condition. Recall that the condition in question is autosomal recessive. Therefore, only individuals carrying two recessive alleles will be affected by the condition (e.g. aa). In contrast, homozygous dominant individuals carry none of the affected alleles (e.g. AA). Option D. Two unaffected parents cannot have an affected child – This option is incorrect because two unaffected parents could indeed have an affected child. If an individual is unaffected, then there are two possible explanations regarding the genotype: either the individual is homozygous dominant (e.g. AA) or heterozygous (e.g. Aa). A carrier of a condition is a heterozygous individual that carries the recessive allele for a condition but is not affected because the expression of the recessive allele is masked by the dominant allele. If two carriers reproduce (Aa x Aa), there is a 25% chance that their offspring is affected by the autosomal recessive condition (Punnett square results in 1 out of 4 being the “aa” genotype).

question.text: Why are prokaryotic cells typically the preferred vector for eukaryotic gene expression?

options.label: A.
options.text: Prokaryotes have different compartments for their post-translational modification

options.label: C.
options.text: Eukaryotic genes are more easily identified with prokaryotic promoters

options.label: D.
options.text: Prokaryotic ribosomes are able to move faster due to their smaller size

options.label: E.
options.text: Prokaryotic nuclei have more efficient transcription factors

explanation.concept_text: This question refers to a genetic engineering technique where scientists insert segments of eukaryotic cDNA (complementary DNA) into prokaryotic cells (such as bacteria) for them to transcribe and translate into proteins. What makes this a powerful technique, and the reason it is the preferred method, is that prokaryotes lack introns , which are the non-coding segments of DNA found in eukaryotic DNA. Recall that, in eukaryotes, DNA is composed of coding segments (exons) and non-coding segments (introns), as seen in the figure below. A useful mnemonic is: E xons = E xpressed  vs I ntrons = I n between. This lack of intros is one of the reasons why in prokaryotes, transcription and translation can occur simultaneously. That is, as RNA Polymerase moves along the DNA strand transcribing the mRNA, ribosomes can immediately start attaching to that emerging mRNA. This makes overall DNA expression in prokaryotes simpler and faster than in eukaryotes and makes it a favorable technique in genetic engineering. Therefore, Option B , Prokaryotic genes lack introns , is the correct answer. It should be noted that for a prokaryote to express eukaryotic DNA, one major obstacle needs to be addressed first: since prokaryotes lack introns, they also lack the cell machinery that performs splicing (removal of non-coding segments). Therefore, a prokaryote would be unable to translate functional proteins if given a DNA strand with introns. To avoid this, before delivering the DNA strand to a prokaryote, scientists remove all non-coding segments from the strand of interest to create a cDNA strand (complementary DNA). This way, no splicing needs to be performed by the prokaryote. Likewise, it is simpler to use a prokaryotic vector rather than a eukaryotic one for expression of the cDNA because there is no risk of prokaryotes attempting to modify the mRNA transcript (in a eukaryotic vector, post-transcriptional and post-translational modification could end up altering the final desired product).
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Prokaryotes have different compartments for their post-translational modification – This option is incorrect because prokaryotes lack compartmentalization Remember that prokaryotes, by definition, lack membrane-bound organelles such as the nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, or Golgi apparatus. Because prokaryotes do not have a nuclear membrane to separate transcription from translation (as seen in eukaryotes), transcription and translation in prokaryotes occur simultaneously in the cytoplasm (as RNA polymerase moves along the DNA strand transcribing DNA into mRNA, ribosomes can immediately start attaching to that emerging mRNA and begin translation). Option C. Eukaryotic genes are more easily identified with prokaryotic promoters – This option is incorrect. The decision to use prokaryotes to express eukaryotic DNA has nothing to do with promoter regions. A promoter is a region of a DNA strand that attracts RNA polymerase to attach and begin transcription. While promoters are a crucial part of gene expression in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes, they are not the reason prokaryotes are used for eukaryotic gene expression, which makes this answer option incorrect. Rather, the main benefit of using prokaryotes is their reliability in gene expression, which is a result of the lack of introns. Prokaryotes do not perform splicing, and therefore, they do not run the risk of invertedly making inaccurate alterations to the final product through splicing. Option D. Prokaryotic ribosomes are able to move faster due to their smaller size – This option is incorrect because this is not a benefit of using prokaryotic gene expression. While it is true that prokaryotic ribosomes are smaller, and it is also true that prokaryotic gene expression as a whole is faster than in eukaryotes, this difference in speed is not caused by the smaller size of prokaryotic ribosomes. Rather, the reason prokaryotic gene expression is faster is because of the coupling of transcription and translation made possible by the lack of nuclear membrane (lack of compartmentalization). Furthermore, the reason prokaryotic cells are preferred for eukaryotic gene expression is not for speed, but for reliability of expressing the final gene product. Option E. Prokaryotic nuclei have more efficient transcription factors – This option is incorrect because prokaryotes do not have nuclei. Recall that one of the defining characteristics of prokaryotes is the lack of membrane-bound organelles such as the nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi, or mitochondria. This answer option incorrectly suggests that prokaryotes have nuclei. Moreover, this answer option also suggests that transcription factors are more efficiently used by prokaryotes, which is incorrect. In reality, transcription factors are much more commonly used by eukaryotes due to the higher degree of gene expression and regulation seen in eukaryotic gene expression. On the other hand, prokaryotes rely much more on operons to regulate their gene expression. An operon is a cluster of genes that control transcription and consist of promoter, operator, and structural genes.

question.text: The genetic variation of a population is MOST likely to be increased by which of the following processes?

explanation.concept_text: Mutation is an event where the DNA sequence is changed. They have a high impact on genetic variation because mutations are changes in the DNA, and secondly, it only takes a single change to create a large effect. This leads to an evolutionary change which is based on the accumulation of multiple mutations.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Natural selection – This option is incorrect . Although this is a process that contributes to population variation, it acts on the results of mutations. Option B. Genetic drift – This option is incorrect because this is the process in which allele frequencies within a population change by chance alone and is thus, a completely random process, unlike natural selection. Option C. Population undergoing bottleneck – This option is incorrect because this occurs when a population’s size is reduced for at least one generation, leading to a reduction in the genetic variation of the population. Option E. Artificial selection – This option is incorrect because this is the process in which intentional reproduction is used to selectively develop particular phenotypic traits.

question.text: If pink-colored flowers are produced when a red-colored flower is bred with a white-colored flower, what does the gene for flower color appear to be an example of?

explanation.concept_text: Incomplete dominance is a form of intermediate inheritance; that is, a type of inheritance in which the alleles from each parent blend together to form a “mixed” or “blended” phenotype in the offspring. This may occur if the two alleles are equally dominant to each other, resulting in a scenario where neither allele can be fully dominant over the other. In the example below, when a red -colored flower (genotype C R C R ) and a white -colored flower (genotype C W C W ) breed and produce a heterozygous offspring that has pink -colored flowers (genotype C R C W ). This trait is a combination of the phenotypes of both alleles. In incomplete dominance, one allele for a specific trait is not completely expressed over its paired allele. Therefore, Option C , Incomplete dominance , is the correct answer. Here is a visualization of this concept: CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Polygenic inheritance - This option is incorrect because polygenic inheritance is not the expression of an intermediate or “blended ” phenotype (as seen in the example above). Instead, polygenic inheritance is the interaction of many genes to shape a single phenotype with continuous variation such as height, skin color, or hair color. Polygenic inheritance can be described as the opposite of pleiotropy, where one gene affects multiple phenotypes. Option B. Complete dominance - This option is incorrect because complete dominance occurs when the dominant allele completely masks the effect of the recessive allele. In the question above, neither phenotype (red vs white) completely masks the other, which makes this answer option incorrect. Most examples of inheritance you are initially exposed to while learning the basics of genetics involve complete dominance. That is, the offspring exhibit only one dominant allele that completely overrides the phenotype of the recessive allele. This is known as simple Mendelian inheritance because this pattern was first described in detail by Gregor Mendel. Option D. Pleiotropy - This option is incorrect because pleiotropy occurs when a single gene affects multiple, seemingly unrelated features or aspects of an organism’s phenotype. For example, sickle cell anemia is the result of only one gene mutation, however, it has numerous consequences on an individual's phenotype beyond anemia, such as organ damage, frequent infections, vision issues, and increased stroke risk. Pleiotropy can be described as the opposite of polygenic inheritance; in polygenic inheritance, multiple genes affect one phenotype (e.g. multiple genes together determine someone’s height). Option E. Co-Dominance - This option is incorrect . In co-dominance, both alleles in the genotype are seen in the phenotype simultaneously (in this example, the flower would have patches of red and white color if there was co-dominance). However, in incomplete dominance, a mixture or “blend” of the alleles in the genotype is seen in the phenotype (pink flowers). Therefore, this option is incorrect.

question.text: A virus infects the eye of a dog, selectively damaging the rod cells. Which of the following would be expected as a result?

options.label: C.
options.text: Inability to see in bright light

explanation.concept_text: Rods are a type of photoreceptors within the retina that are necessary for night vision and vision in dimmer lighting. They mainly occupy the outer edges of the retina. Rod cells contain pigments called rhodopsin , which undergo chemical change when exposed to light rays and cause these photoreceptor cells to signal bipolar cells near the retina, which then send signals to the brain through the optic nerve. Therefore, a defect in rod cells would impair the ability to see in dim (low) lighting. As such, Option A , Inability to see dim light , is the correct answer. Rod cells are commonly confused with cone cells , which are the other type of photoreceptors, responsible for transmitting color vision and sharp images. Use the mnemonic “ C for C olor” ( C one) to remember the difference. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Inability to see colors – This option is incorrect because rods are not responsible for color vision. The photoreceptors responsible for color vision are cones. Moreover, cone cells allow us to focus on fine details and provide our sharpest central vision. Option C. Inability to see in bright light – This option is incorrect . Although rods are very light-sensitive, it would be less likely for damaged rods to show poor performance in environments with bright light compared to dim lighting. Rod cells are responsible for processing dimly lit environments. They contain a photopigment called rhodopsin, which is incredibly sensitive to even tiny amounts of light. Therefore, rod cells are specialized in night vision and any damage to rod cells would hinder vision in dark environments, not bright ones. Option D. Inability to see far distances – This option is incorrect because this would occur because of a lens defect/suboptimal eye shape. This is called myopia and occurs when the lens is too strong, which causes the light rays to focus in front of the retina. This is also called short-sightedness because you can clearly see objects that are within a short distance. Option E. Inability to see near distances – This option is incorrect because this would occur because of a lens defect/suboptimal eye shape. This is called hyperopia and occurs when the lens is too weak, which causes the light rays to focus slightly behind the retina. This is also called long-sightedness because you can clearly see objects that are a long distance away.

question.text: In which component of the eukaryotic cell does the Krebs cycle take place?

explanation.concept_text: In eukaryotic cells, the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle) occurs in the mitochondrial matrix, as shown in the image below. In contrast, prokaryotic cells lack mitochondria and carry out the Krebs cycle in the cytosol. Therefore, Option D , Mitochondrial matrix , is the correct answer. The Krebs cycle is a biochemical pathway that serves as a crucial step of cellular respiration in any organism that uses oxygen to produce energy. Cellular respiration breaks down glucose molecules to generate ATP. To achieve this, the breakdown of glucose begins with glycolysis, which occurs in the cell cytoplasm. Glycolysis uses substrate-level phosphorylation to produce a net gain of 2 ATP molecules, two pyruvate molecules, and two NADH. Each pyruvate molecule enters the mitochondria and undergoes pyruvate oxidation to be converted into acetyl-CoA (acetyl coenzyme A). Each acetyl-CoA then enters the Krebs cycle , and the net result is one ATP, three NADH, and one FADH 2 (high-energy electron carriers). These high-energy electron carriers shuttle high-energy electrons to the Electron Transport Chain (ETC) which is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. The ETC creates a proton gradient that drives ATP production via oxidative phosphorylation, yielding roughly 32 ATP molecules (the majority of ATP in cellular respiration). CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Plasma membrane – This option is incorrect because the Krebs cycle takes place in the mitochondrial matrix. Moreover, neither of the two membranes of the mitochondrion is referred to as a “plasma membrane”. Because of the mitochondrion’s unique double-membrane composition, the mitochondrial membranes are referred to as the “inner” and “outer” membranes. Regardless, neither of these two membranes hosts the Krebs cycle, which makes this answer option incorrect. Option B. Mitochondrial inner membrane – This option is incorrect because it is actually the Electron Transport Chain – not the Krebs cycle – that is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. The Krebs cycle takes place in the mitochondrial matrix. The Electron Transport Chain (ETC) is a crucial component of cellular respiration because this is where oxidative phosphorylation occurs. As electrons move through the protein complexes of the ETC, a proton gradient is formed in the inner mitochondrial matrix. It is this proton gradient that drives ATP synthase, the enzyme that ultimately produces the majority of ATP in cellular respiration. Option C. Cytoplasm – This option is incorrect because the Krebs cycle does not take place in the cytoplasm; the Krebs cycle takes place in the mitochondrial matrix. This is likely the result of the mitochondrion’s history as a once independent energy-producing organism (recall endosymbiotic theory). If the Krebs cycle occurred in the cytoplasm (outside the mitochondrion), then the Electron Transport Chain (inside the mitochondrion) would not receive enough high-energy electron carriers to carry out oxidative phosphorylation. Glycolysis and fermentation are the two main energy-producing processes that take place in the cytoplasm. Option E. Mitochondrial inter-membrane space – This option is incorrect because the Krebs cycle takes place in the mitochondrial matrix and not in the inter-membrane space. The inter-membrane space is the narrow region between the outer and inner mitochondrial membranes. Its main function is to maintain the proton gradient that drives oxidative phosphorylation and, ultimately, the production of ATP (the “end goal” of cellular respiration).

question.text: Most human individuals live to old age but tend to very rapidly die thereafter. What is this characteristic of?

explanation.concept_text: Evolution selects for genetic success; therefore, an organism’s structure, function, and overall behavior are rooted in increasing the possibility of its genes being passed down to the next generation. But how this “goal” is achieved by an organism can vary. Throughout evolution, two main “techniques” have emerged: (1) produce as many offspring as possible while maintaining minimal parental investment into each offspring or (2) produce a low number of offspring but dedicate large amounts of time and energy in maintaining high parental investment for each offspring. Both strategies have proven very successful in an evolutionary context. The difference between them can be distinctly seen in their survivorship curve (a graph that visualizes the proportion of individuals surviving early, middle, and old age). As seen in the figure below, a Type I survivorship curve is characterized by a high rate of survival in early and middle age but sees a steep increase in deaths in old age (that is, most individuals live to old age, after which mortality rates increase dramatically). Type II survivorship curve sees constant mortality rates throughout all ages, and lastly, Type III survivorship curve has high mortality rates in early age, but later plateaus following an exponential decay curve. In other words, species that follow a Type III curve have a high death rate early in life, but those individuals lucky enough to survive that initial period have a good chance of living a long time. R-selected species produce many offspring and dedicate minimal parental investment (e.g. frogs, fish, and rabbits). As a result, most of the offspring die at an early age, therefore, R-selected species exhibit a Type III curve . In contrast, K-selected species produce few offspring and invest more time and resources into each offspring (e.g. humans, elephants, and kangaroos). Because only a few offspring were produced, parental investment can be maintained high, which allows most of the population to survive to old age, after which deaths rapidly increase due to natural causes. Therefore, K-selected species exhibit a Type I survivorship curve. A useful mnemonic to remember the difference is that R ats are R -selected vs K angaroos are K -selected. Since most humans live to old age, at which point death rates rapidly increase, Option D, K-selected species is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Ecological succession – This option is incorrect because ecological succession describes how one community is gradually replaced by another group of species; this does not relate to the survivorship curve of a population. The original scenario posed by the question refers to the recurring trend (Type I survivorship) seen in human populations. In contrast, ecological succession occurs only in instances of significant disturbance in a community such as wildfire, hurricane, or flood. Option B. Stabilizing selection – This option is incorrect because stabilizing selection does not dictate the age at which humans die. Stabilizing selection describes the tendency of intermediate values in a population to be favored over extreme values, forming a bell curve. For example, a new virus kills individuals who are extremely short and extremely tall in a population, while those who are closer to the mean are more likely to survive. This event is considered “stabilizing” because it “selects” for the mean value (closer to the peak of the bell curve). few other types of selection are Directional, Industrial, and Disruptive selection. Option C. R-selected species – This option is incorrect because R-selected species experience the opposite of what is being described in the question. R-selected species experience a Type III survivorship curve, which is characterized by a rapid rate of mortality in the population in early age, which later plateaus in an exponential decay curve. This is a result of minimal parental investment (less attention, care, and resources being invested into each offspring inevitably leads to higher mortality rates). Remember that this is “by design” and is the way with which the population dynamics of such organisms have evolved. Although there is a very steep decline in population in early age, the few individuals that survive are enough to reproduce and keep the lineage alive. In contrast, human populations follow a Type I survivorship curve, characterized by a high rate of survival in early and middle age, followed by a steep increase in deaths in old age. Option E. Cell differentiation – This option is incorrect because cell differentiation is unrelated to the survivorship trends of a population. Cell differentiation is the process by which stem cells become specialized to perform specific functions in a multicellular organism. For example, muscle cells contract to provide movement, nerve cells transmit electrical signals for communication, red blood cells carry oxygen, and skin cells form a protective barrier from the outside world; all these cells originated from stem cells that underwent differentiation. It is important to remember that during cell differentiation, the cell still retains its full original genome. Cells differentiate and “specialize” as a result of the select set of genes they express and not because the genome itself has been changed.

question.text: Organisms that belong to the Phylum Chordata possess all of the following structures at some point in their life EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: The Phylum Chordata is extremely diverse and contains all animals that, at some point in their lives, possess a notochord and a dorsal hollow nerve cord. Note that Option C is almost a true statement. However, chordates actually have a hollow nerve cord – not a solid nerve cord, as suggested by Option C. Therefore, Option C , Dorsal solid nerve cord is the exception, which makes it the correct answer. Because it is hollow, the nerve cord acts as a “tube” that holds the spinal cord and fills up with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) early in development. CSF is crucial to the health of a chordate because it acts as a shock absorber for the spinal cord and brain and helps maintain chemical homeostasis. Moreover, “dorsal” describes the position of the hollow nerve cord as running along the backside of the animal’s body. All chordates contain the following features during development: CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Notochord – This option is incorrect because the notochord is a defining characteristic of all Chordata, hence the “chord” portion of the phylum’s name. This structure develops from the mesoderm and is found in all Chordata at some point in their embryonic development and it functions as support but usually develops into the vertebral column. Option B. Pharyngeal gill slits – This option is incorrect because all Chordata will, at some point in their development, have this structure. Eventually, pharyngeal gill slits either become gills, disappear, or develop into another structure. In humans, the pharyngeal slits eventually develop into the inner ear. While many chordates might not retain functional pharyngeal gill slits as adults , all chordates possess them at some point during their embryonic development. Option D. Muscular postnatal tail – This option is incorrect because this structure is found in Chordata at some point during embryonic development. Most chordates retain this structure even through adulthood. For example, fish, reptiles, birds, and most mammals possess a postnatal tail. This structure, however, is sometimes “lost” by the time the animal reaches adulthood and becomes a vestigial structure. In apes (including humans), the remnant of the muscular post-anal tail is the coccyx, more commonly known as the tailbone.
